repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Problem:
fix https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/33316

Solution:
The `vim.VersionRange:has()` shouldn't have special handling for prereleases (Why would we need it when `__eq`, `__lt`, `__le` already handle prereleases?).

Also see comment https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/33324#issuecomment-2780210160

TODO
- [x] news.txt

Closes https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/33316

comment_data.body:
This doesn't seem like a necessary callout. If they're the same, it wouldn't make sense for them to be "exclusive".

Also 'to' links to 'timeout'.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3973,7 +3973,7 @@ vim.version.range({spec})                                *vim.version.range()*
 <
 
     `:has()` checks if a version is in the range (inclusive `from`, exclusive
-    `to`).
+    `to`. If `from` and `to` are the same, then 'to' will be inclusive).

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
--- `:has()` checks if a version is in the range (inclusive `from`, exclusive `to`).
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -255,7 +255,8 @@ end
 --- }
 --- ```
 ---
---- `:has()` checks if a version is in the range (inclusive `from`, exclusive `to`).
+--- `:has()` checks if a version is in the range (inclusive `from`, exclusive
+--- `to`. If `from` and `to` are the same, then 'to' will be inclusive).

@@ -3973,7 +3973,7 @@ vim.version.range({spec})                                *vim.version.range()*
 <
 
     `:has()` checks if a version is in the range (inclusive `from`, exclusive
-    `to`).
+    `to`. If `from` and `to` are the same, then 'to' will be inclusive).

comment_data.body:
don't need the extra messages. the code is already quite readable. though it was wrong before :)
```suggestion
      assert(not vim.version.range('1.2.3'):has('1.2.3-alpha'))
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -100,17 +100,31 @@ describe('version', function()
       end)
 
       it('[to] not in range ' .. input .. ' to:' .. tostring(range.to), function()
-        if range.to then
+        if range.to and range.to ~= range.from then
           assert(not (range.to < range.to))
           assert(not range:has(range.to))
         end
       end)
+
+      it('[to] in range ' .. input .. ' to:' .. tostring(range.to), function()
+        if range.to and range.to == range.from then
+          assert(range:has(range.to))
+        end
+      end)
     end
 
     it('handles prerelease', function()
-      assert(not vim.version.range('1.2.3'):has('1.2.3-alpha'))
-      assert(vim.version.range('1.2.3-alpha'):has('1.2.3-alpha'))
-      assert(not vim.version.range('1.2.3-alpha'):has('1.2.3-beta'))
+      assert(not vim.version.range('1.2.3'):has('1.2.3-alpha'), '1.2.3 should not have 1.2.3-alpha')

comment_data.body:
worth adding a note here

    -- Per semver spec, prereleases have alphabetical ordering.

comment_regular_data.body:
> This isn't correct. vim.version.range('>=0.12.0'):has('0.12.0-dev') should still return false.

I know that, that's why I added more tests. The added test fails, which means there is something wrong with the logic to compare prerelease or something else. I will check that

@zeertzjq @justinmk I saw a test failed with this line
```lua
assert(not vim.version.range('1.2.3-alpha'):has('1.2.3-beta'))
```
AFAIK, `vim.version.range('1.2.3-alpha')` is same as `vim.version.range('1.2.3-alpha - 1.2.4-alpha')`, so `1.2.3-beta` is supposed to be inside that range, right? But the test expected the opposite

I think you want to make it be like `vim.version.range('1.2.3-alpha')` should includes one and only version `1.2.3-alpha`, but since `vim.VersionRange` is end-exclusive, there is no way to accurately represent such "range". Previously, the code just check if `prerelease` of version is different from `self.from`, then returns false, but it caused #33316.

So I will propose that if a range only includes one version with major, minor and patch like `1.2.3`, it should be parse as `from = 1.2.3, to = 1.2.3` instead of `from = 1.2.3, to = 1.2.4`, because there is no version smaller than a patch. Then the function `vim.VersionRange:has()` will check if `from` and `to` are the same, then `to` will be inclusive.

FYI I tried the [node-semver](https://www.npmjs.com/package/semver) library,
```javascript
// npm i semver
const semver = require('semver')
console.log(semver.satisfies('1.2.4-dev', '1.2.3')) // false
console.log(semver.satisfies('1.2.3-dev', '1.2.3')) // false
```
So even npm doesn't consider a single patch version as an X range like current Nvim

And, build metadata doesn't make a version different, for example
```vim
:=vim.version.parse '1.2.3+ubuntu' == vim.version.parse '1.2.3+win'
" --> true
:=vim.version.parse '1.2.3' == vim.version.parse '1.2.3+win' 
" --> true
```
So I think my proposal is safe to use

> `vim.version.range('1.2.3-alpha')` is same as `vim.version.range('1.2.3-alpha - 1.2.4-alpha')`, so `1.2.3-beta` is supposed to be inside that range, right?

All prereleases are considered "equal". `-alpha` and `-beta` are equal. Or maybe it's alphabetical...

> maybe it's alphabetical...

Yes, it is https://semver.org/#spec-item-11
Btw, is this considered a breaking change?

> Btw, is this considered a breaking change?

No, but worth mentioning in news-changed.

Backport failed for `release-0.11`, because it was unable to cherry-pick the commit(s).

Please cherry-pick the changes locally and resolve any conflicts.
```bash
git fetch origin release-0.11
git worktree add -d .worktree/backport-33324-to-release-0.11 origin/release-0.11
cd .worktree/backport-33324-to-release-0.11
git switch --create backport-33324-to-release-0.11
git cherry-pick -x 092962b07c5753e9d602f5597ad1753b19854561
```
Sorry if I'm wrong, but I thought blackported commits aren't supposed to be mention in `news.txt`, right? (I guess that's why Github Actions fails to backport it)
Not sure. Don't want to discourage news.txt when it's appropriate.

Just means the bot failed and manual backporting is needed. The bot is for convenience, not for restricting what should and should not be backported -- there's a reason it gives instructions for manual backporting. Try following them!

title: fix(vim.version): vim.VersionRange:has() with prerelease
